page.title: 11WATERWAYS (2)
page.content: Every year the river Parrett will flood so somebody has to do something about it. The Wessex Water Authority send people to make walls of mud, taken from the river bank, so that the water doesn't overflow. Two children interviewed one of the men making the mud walls. He told them that in spring the water will come up to about six inches from the top of the bank. In summer the depth of the river varies from six inches at low tide to ten feet at high tide and in the winter from four feet to fifteen feet. At Moorland the river flows only a few yards from some of the houses. If the mud walls were not rebuilt every year there would be great danger of flooding.
